Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted, infilled rock art on rock surface (sandstone?) showing figures of human and two cows with five other cow figures cut off edge of image. Centre: Cow, brown, upright and facing right with bowed head and pronounced udder with white teats. Portion of belly infilled in red. To right is upright human figure, facing right, in brown with arms bent and raised at elbow and red points on knees. Right of this, with hind legs superimposing neck and groin of human figure, is figure of cow in red , turned to side, facing down with belly to left. Calf of similar colour is to left as if standing under cow, with head cut off edge of image. Top left: small cow figure, upright and facing left in brown with hind leg of another above. Right of this is hindquarters and udder of cow with belly to left, cut off edge of image at trunk. Bottom left: head of cow cut off edge of image at neck, upright and facing right. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: Close up of 2013,2034.250. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
